results.headline: Planet Earth Is Blue and So Very Far Away
results.summary_short: “Moon,” presents a vision of life beyond Earth that emphasizes claustrophobia and loneliness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moon

results.headline: Meet Your New Farmer: Hungry Corporate Giant
results.summary_short: “Food, Inc.” is an activist documentary about the big business of feeding Americans all the junk that multinational corporate money can buy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Food, Inc.

results.headline: Up in the Air
results.summary_short: “Blast!” is about a bunch of nerds in Sweden mucking about with an unfathomable contraption attached to a hot air balloon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blast!

results.headline: Sons and the Father Who Made Them
results.summary_short: “Tetro” is a visually lush cinematic fugue about love, ambivalence and two brothers fleeing the dark shadow of their domineering father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tetro

results.headline: An Upscale Leap Forward That Leaves Many Behind
results.summary_short: The actors in “24 City,” an experimental fiction-nonfiction hybrid, bring their own existential realities to their short, touching performances.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 24 City

results.headline: Pair of Brothers in a Grand Ole Soap Opry
results.summary_short: “Tennessee” is an earnest, increasingly preposterous road movie about unhealed family wounds and fraternal bonds.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tennessee

results.headline: A Sexual Orientation Orientation
results.summary_short: Professional and sexual identities are up for grabs in “The Art of Being Straight,” an unpretentious dramedy of postcollege confusion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Art of Being Straight

results.headline: The Vision of an Uncanny Painter
results.summary_short: The energies of Séraphine are devoted to examining the alchemy by which perception is transformed into vision.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seraphine

results.headline: My Big Fat Crowded Athens Tour Bus
results.summary_short: “My Life in Ruins,” Nia Vardalos’s first movie in five years, might as well be titled “How Georgia Got Her Kefi Back.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Life in Ruins

results.headline: Partners in Pain
results.summary_short: “Downloading Nancy” is a nasty exploitation flick tarted up with art-house actors and psychobabble.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Downloading Nancy

results.headline: Trapped Way Back in Time With a Bunch of Dopey Dinosaurs
results.summary_short: The only marginally interesting, if unsurprising, thing about “Land of the Lost” is that a lot of money has been spent on yet another cultural throwaway.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Land of the Lost

results.headline: Terror Outside the Ring
results.summary_short: The documentary “Kassim the Dream” recounts the unusual life story of the boxer Kassim Ouma.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kassim the Dream

results.headline: Studio, Apartment
results.summary_short: The documentary “Herb & Dorothy” looks at how one middle-class couple became the owners of a prized art collection.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Herb and Dorothy

results.headline: Dudes Doing Vegas: Eating and Other Stuff
results.summary_short: In “The Hangover,” Bradley Cooper, Ed Helms and Zach Galifianakis incarnate familiar masculine stereotypes in ways that manage to be moderately fresh.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hangover

results.headline: Practicing Virtue, and Proud of It
results.summary_short: “Away We Go” is about the flight from adulthood, from engagement, from responsibility, even as it cleverly disguises itself as a search for all those things.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Away We Go

results.headline: Going Down in Estonia: Alienation Frozen in Place
results.summary_short: Emboldened by alcohol and steeped in despair, the characters in “Sugisball” lunge for love but would settle for understanding.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Autumn Ball

results.headline: Following a Young Monk’s Journey in Search of His Master’s Reincarnation
results.summary_short: “Unmistaken Child” documents the four-year search of Tenzin Zopa, a gentle, baby-faced 28-year-old Nepalese monk.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unmistaken Child

results.headline: Mud and Guts
results.summary_short: “Drag Me to Hell” has a tonic playfulness that’s unabashedly retro, an indulgent return to Sam Raimi’s goofy, gooey roots.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drag Me to Hell

results.headline: A Plucky Orphan Playing Cupid
results.summary_short: Stephane Gauger’s debut feature, “Owl and the Sparrow,” is a charming little movie, nothing more.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Owl and the Sparrow

results.headline: The Pitfalls of Outsourcing
results.summary_short: “Offshore” shuttles between American anger and Indian industriousness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Offshore
